title: Quantitative and Categorical Differences
question_text: Which of the following statements correctly describes a difference between a quantitative and a categorical variable?

choices.text: A quantitative variable is always described using a numerical value, while a categorical variable is never described using numerical values.

A quantitative variable describes a characteristic of an individual based upon a numerical measure of that characteristic, while a categorical variable describes a characteristic of an individual by identifying a category or group to which the characteristic belongs.
A quantitative variable can provide very specific information about an individual, while a categorical variable can only provide general information about an individual.
A quantitative variable cannot be described using units of measurement, while a categorical variable is always described using units of measurement.
A quantitative variable can only be used to describe a characteristic of an individual, while a categorical variable can only be used to describe a characteristic of a group.
